questions.text: Which of the following equations is used to calculate the equilibrium potential for an ion?
questions.solution:
Equilibrium potential for an ion is calculated using the Nernst equation. 

When there is a concentration gradient for an ion across the membrane, the ion tends to diffuse down the concentration gradient. The electric potential that exactly opposes this net diffusion is called the equilibrium potential for that ion. This is calculated using the Nernst equation.

It is expressed as the potential inside the cell (intracellular potential relative to the extracellular potential).

To calculate the value of the equilibrium potential:

Note: In this formula, the choice of concentration of the ion placed in the numerator and denominator does not matter because the formula is only used to derive the numerical value and not the sign ( +/- ). Mathematically, log (100/10) = 1  and log (10/100) = - 1. Hence, changing the numerator and denominator only changes the sign and the numerical value remains the same.

This equation is used only to derive the numerical value of the potential. It is NOT used to derive the sign/charge (+/-).

The sign/charge is derived from logic:

  • In a positive (+) ion, if the concentration of the + ion is greater outside, then the + ion moves from outside to inside. The intracellular potential becomes more + relatively. Hence, the potential will be positive.
  • In a positive (+) ion, if the concentration of the + ion is greater inside, then the + ion moves from inside to outside. The intracellular potential becomes more - relatively (as + ion moves outside). Hence the potential will be negative.
  • In a negative (-) ion, if the concentration of the - ion is greater outside, then the - ion moves from outside to inside. The intracellular potential becomes more - relatively. Hence the potential will be negative.
  • In a negative (-) ion, if the concentration of the - ion is greater inside, then the - ion moves from inside to outside. The intracellular potential becomes more + relatively (as - ion moves outside). Hence the potential will be positive.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to calculate the equilibrium potential for diffusion of multiple ions?
questions.solution:
The Goldman equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential when the membrane is permeable to several different ions.

Goldman-Hodgkin-Katz equation

Here,

  • P= permeability of the membrane to each ion, and
  • C= concentrations of the respective ions on the inside (i) and outside (o) of the membrane.

The Na+, K+ and Cl- are the most important ions involved in the development of membrane potentials in nerve fibres and muscle fibres.

choices.text: Effect of one non-diffusible ion on the distribution of other non-diffusible ions
Effect of one permeant ion on the distribution of other permeant ions
Effect of a permeant ion on the distribution of nondiffusible ions
Effect of a non-diffusible ion on the distribution of permeant ions

questions.solution:
Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium explains the effect of a non-diffusible ion on the distribution of permeant ions.

Consider the situation depicted below, 

The membrane is permeable to K+ and Cl-. However, it is impermeable to the proteins. The impermeable protein molecules hinder the movement of K+ (negative charge of the proteins holding back positive charge of the K+) and favor the movement of Cl- (like charges repel). According to the Gibbs-Donnan equation, at equilibrium, the concentration ratios of diffusible ions are equal across the membrane.

questions.text: Extracellular concentration of a positive ion (with valency = 1)  is 100mmol/L and its intracellular concentration is 10mmol/L, the potential across the membrane using Nernst equation is (mV)_______
questions.solution:
The potential of a positive ion across the membrane using Nernst equation is +60mV.

Where, z is valency in the formula.

Deriving the numerical value: 

EMF = 61/1 *log 10/100

         = 61

The choice of concentration of the ion placed in the numerator and denominator does not matter because the formula is only used to derive the numerical value and not the sign ( +/- ). Mathematically, log (100/10) = 1  and log (10/100) = - 1. Hence, changing the numerator and denominator only changes the sign and the numerical value remains the same.

Deciding the sign/charge: A positive ion with greater concentration extracellularly will try to diffuse inside the cell. A positive intracellular potential is required to prevent this. Hence the sign/charge (potential) is positive (+).

Hence, the potential across the membrane using the Nernst equation is +60mV (the closest answer chosen).

Related Pearl: Nernst potential for different ions

Ion

 Valency (Z)  Equilibrium potential (mV)
 Na+ +1  +60
 K+ +1  -90

Cl-

-1

-70

Ca2+

+2

+130

Mg2+

+2

+9

questions.text: Extracellular concentration of a negative ion (with valency = 1) is 10mmol/L and its intracellular concentration is 100mmol/L. The equilibrium potential for this ion using Nernst equation is (mV) _____
questions.solution:
The equilibrium potential for this negative ion using the Nernst equation is +60mV.

Where, z is valency in the formula.

Deriving the numerical value: 

EMF = 61/1 *log 100/10

         = 61

Deciding the sign/charge: A negative ion with greater concentration intracellularly will try to diffuse outside the cell. A positive intracellular potential is required to prevent this. Hence, the potential is positive. 

Hence, the Nernst potential is +60mV (the closest answer chosen).

questions.text: What is the Nernst potential for K+ in milivolt (mV)?
questions.solution:
The Nernst potential for K+ is −90mV.

Note:

  • For K+ ions, the concentration gradient is directed outward and the electrical gradient is directed inward.
  • In general, all excitable cell membranes at rest are maximally permeable to K+ and thus their RMP is close to equilibrium potential of K+ ion.

questions.text: Which of the following ions have the highest positive equilibrium potential?
questions.solution:
The ion with the highest positive equilibrium potential is Na+ that is +60mV.

questions.text: The resting membrane potential of a nerve fibre depends on ______
questions.solution:
The resting membrane potential (RMP) of a nerve fibre depends on the diffusion of both K+ and Na+ and the Na+-K+ ATPase pump.

The most predominant factor, however, is the diffusion of K+ ions. This is because, at rest, the permeability of the membrane of the nerve fibre to K+ ions is almost 100 times greater than that to Na+. 

Related Pearl: Resting membrane potential (RMP) in tissues

RMP(mV)

Neuron

-70

Skeletal muscle

-90

Myocardial muscle

-90

Smooth muscle

-20 to -65

questions.text: Resting membrane potential of the nerve fibre is equal to equilibrium potential of ______
questions.solution:
Resting membrane potential of a nerve fiber is equal to the equilibrium potential of Cl-  and is -70mV.

questions.text: Driving force of a charged ion is____

choices.text: Measured membrane potential - calculated equilibrium potential
Measured membrane potential  +  calculated equilibrium potential
Calculated equilibrium potential  - Measured membrane potential

questions.solution:
The driving force on a charged ion is measured membrane potential (Em) - calculated equilibrium potential (Ex).

Net driving force (mV) = Em - Ex

where,

Em = Actual membrane potential (mV)

Ex = Equilibrium potential for X (mV)

When the driving force is negative (i.e., Em is more negative than the ion’s equilibrium potential), then

  • A cation will enter the cell
  • An anion will leave the cell

questions.text: If the membrane potential of this cell is -80mV the driving force is greatest for which ion?
questions.solution:
The driving force is greatest for Ca2+.

Net driving force is the difference between the membrane potential and the equilibrium potential for that particular ion. Hence Em - EX. Where:

Em = Actual membrane potential (mV) = -80mV

EX = Equilibrium potential for X (mV) 

For the respective ions:

E Ca2+ = +120 ;  Driving force = -80 – (120) = -200mV

E Na+ = +60 ; Driving force= -80 – (60) =-140mV

E K+ = -90, Driving force = -80 – (-90) =10mV

E Cl-= -70, Driving force = -80 – (-70) =-10mV

Thus, Ca2+ will have the largest driving force and it will move inwards or into the cell.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is used to study the current flow across single ion channel?
questions.solution:
The patch-clamp technique is used to record ion current flow through a single protein channel. 

In the patch-clamp experiment, a small pipette is carefully maneuvered to seal off a portion of a cell membrane. The pipette has an electrode bathed in an appropriate solution that allows for the recording of electrical changes through any pore in the membrane.

questions.text: What is the effect on the cellular membrane when the extracellular concentration of K+ is decreased?
questions.solution:
When the extracellular concentration of K+ is decreased (hypokalemia), there is increased negativity of RMP.

RMP predominantly depends on the diffusion of K+ from inside to outside the cell. This diffusion depends on the concentration gradient with the inside of the cell having a larger concentration of K+ ions. When the extracellular concentration of K+ decreases, the concentration gradient for K+ rises. Therefore, more K+ ions diffuse out of the cell. This leaves the inside of the cell more negative relative to the extracellular space. This increases the negativity of the RMP, leaving the membrane hyperpolarised.

questions.text: X, Y, Z are three permeable ions. X = -50 and Y = -30. At RMP, if there is no net electrogenic transfer, what is the value of Z?
questions.solution:
No net electro genic transfer at RMP means X + Y + Z = 0

Since X = -50 and Y = -30, then Z must be +80 since (-80 +80 = 0)
